title-group.article-title: Functional magnetic resonance imaging correlates of cognitive performance in patients with a clinically isolated syndrome suggestive of multiple sclerosis at presentation: an activation and connectivity study

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Neuroscience, Scientific Institute and “Vita-Salute” University, Hospital San Raffaele, Milan, Italy.
2Universitat Jaume I, Castelló de la Plana, Spain.
3Servicio de Neuroinmunología, Hospital La Fe, Valencia, Spain.

author-notes.corresp: Cristina Forn, PhD, Dept. Psicologia Bàsica, Clínica i Psicobiologia, Campus Riu Sec, Fac. Ciències Humanes i Socials, Universitat Jaume I, E-12071 Castelló, Spain Email: forn@psb.uji.es

abstract.p: Background/Objective: To assess whether abnormalities on functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) are related to cognitive function in patients at presentation with clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) suggestive of multiple sclerosis.

Methods: Eighteen patients with CIS and 15 healthy controls (HCs) performed an adapted fMRI version of the Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT). According to their PASAT performance, CIS patients were divided into two groups: 10 with a low PASAT performance (<1 SD from the mean value of HCs) were considered ‘cognitive impairment’ (CI); eight patients were defined as ‘cognitively preserved’ (CP). Between-group differences in the patterns of brain activations and effective connectivity were assessed.

Results: During PASAT, compared to HCs, CIS patients showed increased activations of the bilateral inferior parietal lobe (IPL), bilateral precuneus, bilateral middle frontal gyrus (MFG), left anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), left claustrum, right thalamus and right caudate nucleus. When CIS patients were analyzed, the CI group had a more significant activation of the bilateral IPL than HCs and CP patients. Compared to CP patients, they also had more significant recruitment of the right superior parietal lobe, right cerebellum, left MFG and left ACC. The analysis of effective connectivity showed stronger connections between several regions of the right hemisphere involved in working memory function in CI patients versus CP and HC.
Conclusions: During performance of the PASAT, CIS patients show abnormalities in the patterns of cortical recruitment and connectivity related to the level of their cognitive impairment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In about 85% of patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), the clinical onset of the disease is a clinically isolated syndrome (CIS), involving the optic nerve, brainstem or spinal cord. Approximately 50–80% of these patients already have visible lesions on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, consistent with prior disease activity.1

It is known that cognitive deficits play an important role in MS and that they impact significantly on patient activities of daily living and quality of life.2 However, relatively little is known about the prevalence of cognitive impairment at the onset of the disease in CIS patients. Recent studies in this clinical population have described the presence of cognitive deficits ranging from mild to moderate, depending on the criteria used to define such an impairment.3–6

Cognitive dysfunction in MS involves several domains including information processing speed, attention, memory and frontal executive functions.7 This heterogeneity is usually not observed in individuals with CIS, in whom only deficits of information processing speed and working memory have been described.5 A characterization of the cognitive profile of CIS patients as well as the mechanisms underlying the preservation of some cognitive functions in this condition might improve our understanding of the development of cognitive impairment in MS. Indeed, it has been recently demonstrated that cognitive deficits in CIS patients have a prognostic value to predict subsequent conversion to definite MS.8

In relation to this, a valuable tool is represented by functional MRI (fMRI). In the last few years, fMRI studies have disclosed differences in the patterns of brain recruitment between MS patients and healthy controls (HCs) when performing various active tasks. Some of these studies have suggested that, at least in some cases, an altered pattern of brain recruitment might contribute to limit the clinical consequences of tissue damage.9–11 Brain reorganization has also been observed in CIS patients when performing cognitive12 and motor tasks.13 To better characterize differences in the patterns of brain activations between MS patients and HCs, a few studies have also analyzed functional/effective connectivity among different brain regions.14–18 However, only a seminal study has shown an increased connectivity of brain regions of the working memory network in CIS compared to HCs.19

To examine possible early fMRI cognition-associated abnormalities, we studied a sample of CIS patients using an adapted version of the Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT), which has been previously applied in several fMRI studies of patients with definite MS.9,10,12 This task is sensitive to abnormalities of working memory and information processing speed. In addition, to characterize further the possible differences in brain recruitment between CIS patients and HC, we also run an effective connectivity analysis to obtain a more complete picture of the functional abnormalities associated to cognitive performance in these patients.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Eighteen right-handed patients at presentation with CIS suggestive of MS and paraclinical evidence of dissemination in space20 were recruited consecutively at the Hospital Universitari La Fe and the Hospital Clinic Universitari MS Unit, Valencia, Spain. All patients were examined within 3 months from the first clinical episode and were free of steroids treatment for at least 1 month. Alternative neurological diseases were excluded by appropriate investigations.21,22 Exclusion criteria were concomitant therapy with antidepressants, psychoactive drugs, and a history of major medical, neurological or psychiatric disorders as well as drug and alcohol abuse. Depression was excluded with the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI). We also assessed fatigue in CIS patients using the Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS).23 There were 10 women and eight men, and their mean age was 32.9 years (range = 18–47 years). Oligoclonal bands were found in the cerebrospinal fluid of all patients. Disability was rated using the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) Score.24 Fifteen aged-matched right-handed individuals with no history of neurological or psychiatric diseases served as controls.

sec.title: Neuropsychological assessment
sec.p: Following neurological assessment and prior to the MRI acquisition, all participants were assessed by an experienced neuropsychologist, blinded to clinical and MRI findings. This assessment included the Brief Repeatable of Neuropsychological test (BRB-N) validated in a Spanish population,25 the Matrix subtest included in the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale III Battery (WAIS III),26 which was used to match groups in term of their intelligence quotients (IQs).

sec.title: MRI acquisition
sec.p: Using a 3.0 T scanner (Siemens Trio; Siemens, Erlangen, Germany), the following sequences of the brain were acquired from all participants: (1) axial T2-weighted fast spin echo (TR/TE = 6740/97; ETL = 15; FOV = 250 × 250 mm; matrix size = 256 × 256; 40 contiguous slices; slice thickness = 3 mm); (2) axial echo-planar imaging (TR/TE = 3000/50 ms; flip angle = 90°; FOV = 250 × 250 mm; matrix size = 64 × 64; 29 contiguous slices, slice thickness = 4.5 mm) during the PASAT task.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: Participants were instructed to perform the fMRI-adapted auditory PASAT task.10 PASAT consisted of a block design paradigm with six blocks of 1 min each: three for the control condition and three for the active condition. In the PASAT task, a one-digit number between 1 and 9 was randomly presented every 3 s. During the control condition, participants were instructed to repeat the last number heard. During the active condition, participants performed the PASAT task, which involved adding up the last two numbers heard. Subjects were asked to give overt verbal responses, which were recorded by an observer inside the scanner room. The stimuli for the tasks were presented using fMRI-compatible headphones (VisuaStim; Resonance Technologies, Inc, Los Angeles, California, USA). The sound volume was adjusted so that each participant could hear the stimuli of the PASAT test properly. Before fMRI was performed, all subjects underwent a 10-min practice session, which included different stimuli presented in the scanner. Foam cushioning was used to immobilize their head within the coil in order to minimize motion artifacts.

sec.title: Statistical analysis of clinical and cognitive data
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using the Statistical Software Package (Statsoft, Inc, Tulsa, Oklahoma, USA). Inter-group comparisons were made in two steps. First, HCs and CIS patients were compared in terms of their neuropsychological performance. This analysis showed no difference between the two groups. As a second step, and as previously described,12 CIS patients were divided into two groups according to their performance at PASAT, based on the strategy suggested by Sepulcre et al.:25 patients with PASAT performance 1 SD below the mean of HC were considered as cognitively impaired (CI) (n = 10). One-way ANOVA and the Fisher least significant difference (LSD) post hoc test were used to analyze the differences among the three groups for clinical and cognitive data.

sec.title: MRI analysis
sec.p: All MRI post-processing was performed by a single experienced observer, who was unaware of subjects’ identity. T2 lesions were identified and T2 lesion load (LL) measured using the Jim software (Version 4.0; Xinapse Systems, Northants, UK; http://www.xinapse.com).

fMRI data were analyzed using the Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM5) software (Wellcome Department of Cognitive Neurology, London, UK). Prior to the statistical analysis, all images were reoriented according to the anterior–posterior commissural line, realigned to the first one, spatially normalized into the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space, and smoothed with an 8 mm Gaussian kernel filter. SPM calculation was based on the General Lineal Model.27 The motion parameters estimated during realignment were included in the statistical analysis as regressors. First-level task-related contrast images were created for each subject and then used in a second-level random-effect analysis (one-sample t-test) to define the brain patterns of recruitment in each group separately (controls and CIS patients), using a threshold of p < 0.001 false dicovery rate (FDR) corrected, and a minimum cluster extent (k) of 20 contiguous voxels. Between-group comparisons were assessed using a one-way ANOVA, with a threshold for significance set at p < 0.05 FDR corrected, with a minimum cluster extent (k) of 20 contiguous voxels. In CIS patients, the correlation between fMRI activations during PASAT performance and T2 LL was assessed using a linear regression analysis.

sec.title: Effective connectivity analysis
sec.p: Dinamic Causal Modeling (DCM) is a mathematical framework which allows the characterization of effective connectivity, defined as the causal influence that one brain region exerts over another.28 It requires defining an a priori model, usually chosen among possible alternative models using a Bayesian model selection procedure.29 In our case, this model was established based on brain areas known to be related to working memory, as shown by several previous fMRI studies.9,10,12 The areas selected were the left (L) and right (R) middle third of the middle frontal gyrus (MFG), the L and R inferior frontal gyrus (IFG), the L and R anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), and the L and R inferior parietal lobe (IPL). Using the VOI toolbox of SPM5, time series (adjusted for the effect of interest) were extracted from a spherical volume (5 mm radius) centered at the most significant voxel within each cluster of the SPMt map, displaying in each subject the brain areas active during the PASAT task at p < 0.001, uncorrected. We assumed that the effect of the task entered the network via the activation of the L MFG.

The Bayesian model selection29 was performed to test which of the two possible DCM models, including the previous areas, fitted better the data of the two study groups. The first DCM model (M1) assumed a bilinear interconnection between all the above-mentioned areas. The second (M2) was identical to the model previously proposed by Au Duong et al.,19 and considered only the connections shown in Figure 1 as possible connections. The comparison of the two models showed that the M2 model was superior to M1 in both HC (Bayesian factor BF of M1 = 9.001 × 10−66 vs. BF of M2 = 1.111 × 1065) and CIS patients (BF of M1 = 1.705 × 10−11 vs. BF of M2 = 1.132 × 10112). As a consequence, the intrinsic connectivity coefficients of M2 were estimated for each subject using a Bayesian approach.

caption.p: (A) Cognitive model of working memory used for dynamic causal modeling (DCM) analysis from Au Duong et al.19 (B) Inter-group differences in effective connectivity in the working memory network during the Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT). Dotted black lines show differences between cognitively impaired (CI) patients compared to cognitive preserved (CP) patients. Dashed black lines show differences between CI patients compared to both healthy controls (HC) and CP patients. See text for further results.

sec.p: A multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) was used to examine inter-group differences in the strength of connectivity of the previously estimated DCM coefficients. A correlation analysis was performed to assess the relationship between T2 LL and connectivity strengths in CIS patients.

sec.title: Demographic, clinical, neuropsychological and conventional MRI findings
sec.p: Table 1 summarizes the main demographic, clinical and conventional MRI findings from CIS patients as well as their performance at PASAT. Table 2 presents the main demographic, neuropsychological, and conventional MRI characteristics of the three study groups.

caption.p: Individual characteristics of patients at presentation with clinically isolated syndrome CIS suggestive of multiple sclerosis

fn.p: EDSS: Expanded Disability Status Scale, PASAT: Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test.

caption.p: Main demographic, clinical, neuropsychological and magnetic resonance imaging characteristics of the three study groups

fn.p: HC: healthy controls, CI: cognitively impaired, C: cognitively preserved, EDSS: Expanded Disability Status Scale, WAIS: Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale III Adult, SRT: Selective reminding test, SPART: Spatial Recall test, SDMT: Symbol digit modalities test, WLGT: word list generation test, PASAT: Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test, BDI: Beck depression inventory, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

sec.p: EDSS scores (p = 0.001) and T2 LL (p = 0.03) were significantly different between CP and CI patients. CI patients showed more errors at the behavioral PASAT task compared to HCs (p = 0.04) and CP patients (p = 0.001). Similar results were obtained when analyzing the fMRI PASAT test (p = 0.04 vs. HCs, and p = 0.002 vs. CP patients). FSS did not differ between CP and CI patients (p < 0.52).

sec.title: Within-group activations
sec.p: The results of within-group activations during the PASAT are summarized in Table 3 and illustrated in Figure 2. Both HCs and CIS patients showed a recruitment of several areas in the frontal and parietal lobes, bilaterally, as well as areas that are part of the working memory network, bilaterally.

caption.p: Areas significantly activated during the Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT) in healthy controls (HC) and patients with clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) (one-sample t test in each group; p < 0.001, FDR corrected, k = 20)

Areas showing activations during the Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT) in healthy controls (HC) (A) and patients at presentation with a clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) suggestive of multiple sclerosis (B). Both groups recruited regions located in the frontal and parietal lobes as well as areas that are part of the working memory network, bilaterally (p < 0.001 FDR-corrected, k = 20). Images are in neurological convention (left is left).

sec.title: Between-group comparisons
sec.p: During PASAT, compared to HCs, CIS patients experienced a more significant recruitment of the bilateral IPL, bilateral precuneus, bilateral MFG, left ACC, left claustrum, right thalamus and right caudate nucleus. When CIS patients were analyzed according to their PASAT performance, the CI group had a more significant activation of the bilateral IPL than HC and CP patients. Compared to CP patients, they also had a more significant activation of the right superior parietal lobe, right cerebellum, left MFG and left ACC (Table 4, Figure 3). No areas were significantly more activated in CP patients versus HCs and CI patients.

caption.p: Areas showing significant activation differences between groups (p < 0.05, FDR corrected), k = 20 voxels

fn.p: HC: healthy controls, CI: cognitively impaired, CP: cognitively preserved, MNI: Montreal Neurological Institute.

caption.p: (A) Areas showing increased activations in patients at presentation with a clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) compared to healthy controls (HC); (B) cognitively impaired (CI) patients compared to cognitive preserved (CP) CIS patients; and (C) CI patients compared to HC during the Paced Auditory Serial Addition Test (PASAT) (p < 0.05 FDR-corrected, k = 20). Images are in neurological convention (left is left).

sec.title: Analysis of effective connectivity
sec.p: Inter-group differences in the strength of connectivity coefficients are summarized in Table 5 and Figure 1. Compared to both HCs and CP patients, CI patients had an increased connectivity between the: (1) R IFG and R IPL (p = 0.002 vs. HC, and p = 0.0005 vs. CP patients); (2) L IPL and R IPL (p = 0.008 vs. HC, and p = 0.0005 vs. CP patients); and (3) R IPL and R IFG (p = 0.003 vs. HC, and p = 0.01 vs. CP patients). Compared to CP, CI patients also experienced an increased connectivity between the: R ACC and R IPL (p = 0.009), and R MFG and R IFG (p = 0.01). No difference was found between CP patients and HCs.

caption.p: Significant differences in path coefficients (reported as means and standard deviations) between patients with clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) and healthy controls (multivariate analysis of variance)

fn.p: HC: Healthy controls, CP: cognitively preserved, CI: cognitively impaired, ACC: anterior cingulate cortex, MFG: middle frontal gyrus, IPL: inferior parietal lobe, IFG: inferior frontal gyrus, R: right, L: left, SD: standard deviation.

sec.title: Analysis of correlation
sec.p: In CIS patients, no correlation was found between T2 LL and PASAT-related fMRI activations as well as coefficients of connectivity.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study extends our knowledge about the functional changes which can occur in patients at presentation with a CIS suggestive of MS. To detect subtle changes in cognitive functions, we used an adapted version of the PASAT, a task that assesses information processing speed and working memory, since these functions are known to be altered in these patients.5

In line with the results of previous studies,9,10,12 when compared to HCs, CIS patients showed an increased recruitment of several regions mainly located in the frontal and parietal lobes, bilaterally. All of these regions contribute to different aspects of working memory processing and the majority of them have been demonstrated to have a load-depending activity during working memory tasks.30,31

Notably, when CIS patients were subdivided into CI and CP according to their PASAT performance, significant differences emerged between the study groups, not only in the patterns of cortical recruitment, but also in the strengths of functional connections among different brain areas. Compared to the other two groups, CI patients experienced an increased recruitment of areas located in the IPL, bilaterally, which are known to be involved in the maintenance and manipulation of a working memory information.32 Compared to CP patients, they also experienced an additional recruitment of regions located in the fronto-parietal lobes and cerebellum, which is known to be involved in high-level cognitive functions and conflict adaptation.33 It is worth noting that, in order to be able to detect early markers of cognitive dysfunction in CIS, we defined as CI those patients with 1 SD difference in PASAT performance with respect to the mean of HC (while the cut-off usually applied is 2 or 1.5 SD).

Taken together, our results indicate that, even in patients with such a subclinical impairment, an increased pattern of cortical recruitment does occur, which might contribute to limit the clinical consequences of disease-related tissue injury. Clearly, we can not completely rule out that other factors, including different mechanisms involved in error processing or different level of fatigue during PASAT performance among groups might contribute to explain, at least partially, our findings. In this perspective, it is worth noting that a previous study34 which recruited only MS patients with fatigue showed that a challenging mental task, such as PASAT, can alter the pattern of cerebral activations on an unrelated motor task in fatigued MS patients.

The analysis of effective connectivity, which was based on the model of brain interconnections for PASAT performance previously proposed by Au Duong et al.,19 allowed us to better characterize the pattern of fMRI abnormalities in CIS patients. In particular, compared to CP, CI patients experienced stronger connections between the R MFG and R IFG and between the R ACC and R IPL. They also had an increased connectivity between the R IFG and R IPL and between the L and R IPL compared to both CP patients and HC, thus indicating an increased task demand for the R hemisphere in these patients. The notion that an increased recruitment of areas of the R hemisphere has a critical role for cognitive performance of MS patients agrees with previous activation9,35,36 and connectivity14 studies performed in patients with CIS and relapsing–remitting MS, as well as with several studies of the motor network (for a review, see Filippi and Rocca37) which showed that a recruitment of homologous regions of the two hemispheres is one of the main compensatory mechanisms, at least at the earliest clinical phases of the disease. Differently from previous studies, which found abnormalities of brain recruitment in patients without overt clinical impairment38,39 our analysis did not reveal any abnormality of activation and connectivity between CP CIS patients and HCs. Clearly, we can not exclude the possibility that our study was underpowered to detect such a difference, considering the relatively small size of this group. Another factor which might contribute to explain these findings is the relatively high PASAT performance of our CP patients (even if it was not significantly different from that of HCs).

In this study, we carefully selected a cohort of de novo CIS patients that were studied within 2 months from the diagnosis. Even using such a strict criterion, differences among CIS patients were found using fMRI. This is in line with the results of a previous study of the motor system38 which showed an increased recruitment of several areas of the motor network in CIS patients assessed within 3 months from the onset of the clinical symptoms. Interestingly, compared to CP, CI patients also had a higher EDSS score and T2 LL. It is noteworthy that the analysis of correlation showed no association between T2 LL and fMRI abnormalities in the whole sample of CIS patients. These results are in agreement with those of previous studies of the motor system in CIS patients38,39 and suggest that other factors, such as diffuse abnormalities in the normal-appearing brain tissues and/or damage to strategic white matter fiber bundles, might be associated with the observed fMRI findings.

These results strengthen the notion that CIS patients are a heterogeneous population and call for a comprehensive characterization of functional and structural MRI abnormalities in patients at disease onset also in the perspective of identifying those patients at a higher risk of evolution to definite MS. Indeed, a seminal study showed that an abnormal pattern of cortical recruitment at disease onset could contribute to identify those CIS patients evolving to definite MS after 1 year.40

ack.p: This research has been supported by grants provided by the Alicia Koplowitz Foundation to Cristina Forn, and the Consolider-Ingenio 2010 Program (Spanish Ministry of Science and Education) to C. Ávila.
